name: Sundowners Bar
description: Perched right on the water at the end of West End's main drag, Sundowners is where everyone ends up at some point. The sunsets here are legitimately spectacular — the bar faces due west with unobstructed views. Frozen cocktails are strong and reasonably priced. The food is decent bar fare (fish tacos, burgers, nachos), but you're really here for the vibe and the view. Friday nights get packed with a mix of dive instructors, expats, and tourists. The dock seating fills up fast, so arrive by 4:30pm if you want a waterside spot. They accept both USD and Lempira, and the bartenders know how to pour. It's one of those places that feels like a movie set for a Caribbean bar — except it's real and the drinks are cold.
insiderTip: Grab a dock seat by 4:30pm for the best sunset view. Friday nights have the best crowd — mostly dive instructors and expats.
addressDescription: At the very end of the main road in West End, right on the water

name: Coconut Tree Divers
description: One of the most respected dive operations on the island, Coconut Tree has been running trips on the Mesoamerican Barrier Reef since 2003. Small group sizes (max 6 divers per guide) mean you actually see marine life instead of scaring it away. Their instructors are patient and experienced — great for nervous first-timers and advanced divers alike. The shop is right on the water in West End, so you literally walk off the dock onto the boat. They run morning two-tank dives and afternoon single tanks daily. Equipment is well-maintained and relatively new. If you're doing your PADI certification, this is where most long-term travelers on the island recommend.
insiderTip: Book your Open Water certification here — it's one of the cheapest places in the world to get PADI certified, and the reef is world-class.
addressDescription: On the waterfront in West End, near the main intersection

name: Cannibal Cafe
description: Don't let the name scare you — Cannibal Cafe serves some of the best wood-fired pizza on the island. Tucked into West End's main strip, this open-air spot has a relaxed vibe with mismatched furniture and string lights. The thin-crust pizzas are cooked in a real wood-burning oven, and the dough is made fresh daily. The garlic shrimp pizza is legendary. They also do solid pastas and salads. It's a go-to for divers coming off afternoon boats who want something hearty without breaking the bank. Service can be slow when it's busy — this is island time, not New York. Grab a Salva Vida beer and enjoy the wait.
insiderTip: The garlic shrimp pizza is the move. Also try the daily pasta special — it's usually better than the menu items.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, across from the dive shops

name: West Bay Beach
description: Consistently ranked among the top beaches in the Caribbean, and it lives up to the hype. The sand is powder-white, the water is ridiculously clear, and you can snorkel right off the shore to see coral and tropical fish without a boat. The beach stretches for about a mile along the western tip of the island. The north end near the resorts has chair and umbrella rentals; the south end near the path from West End is more low-key. On cruise ship days it gets crowded, especially between 10am and 2pm. If you walk past all the resort chairs heading south, you'll find quieter stretches. There's no entrance fee — the beach is public despite what resort staff might imply.
insiderTip: The beach is public — don't let anyone charge you an entrance fee. Walk south past the resorts for quieter sand. Bring your own snorkel gear to save $15.
addressDescription: Western tip of Roatán, accessible via road from West End or water taxi

name: Roatan Brewing Company
description: The island's only craft brewery, and it's surprisingly good. Located in a breezy open-air space in West End, they brew a rotating selection of ales and lagers that are miles better than the standard Salva Vida and Port Royal you'll find everywhere else. The Island Blonde is crisp and easy-drinking, perfect for the heat. The Coconut Porter is polarizing but worth trying. They do flights of four beers for a reasonable price, and the food menu — burgers, wings, loaded fries — is solid drinking food. Live music some weekends. The owner is usually around and happy to talk beer. A welcome change from the rum-punch-and-Presidente scene.
insiderTip: Try the flight of four beers to sample everything. The Coconut Porter is unique to the island. Thursday nights usually have live acoustic music.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, near the entrance to the village

name: The Lighthouse Restaurant
description: Fine dining on the beach in West Bay — this is where you go for a special night out. The seafood is impeccable: whole red snapper, lobster tail (in season from July to February), and ceviche that actually tastes like the ocean. The setting is romantic with tables right in the sand, candles, and soft lighting. It's not cheap by Roatan standards, but the quality justifies the price. The wine list is surprisingly good for a small Caribbean island. Reservations are recommended on weekends and during high season. Dress code is 'island dressy' — no flip flops or board shorts, but a collared shirt isn't required. Service is attentive without being hovering.
insiderTip: Lobster is only available July through February — if it's on the menu outside those months, it's frozen. Reserve a beachfront table for sunset.
addressDescription: On the beachfront in West Bay, south side near the resorts

name: Island Pearl Rentals
description: The most reliable car and scooter rental on the west side of the island. They actually maintain their vehicles — a rarity on Roatan where rental cars can be sketchy. Toyota Hilux pickups are the best option for the island's rough roads, and they usually have several available. Scooters start cheap per day and are perfect for zipping between West End and West Bay. They'll deliver the vehicle to your hotel or the cruise port. Insurance is included in the price, which is not always the case elsewhere. The owner Jorge is responsive on WhatsApp and will sort out any issues fast. Book at least a day ahead during high season (December-April).
insiderTip: Book via WhatsApp at least a day ahead — they sell out during cruise ship days. Ask for a Toyota Hilux if you're heading east of French Harbour.
addressDescription: Near the entrance to West End village, on the main road heading toward Sandy Bay

name: Native Sons Water Taxi
description: The fastest and most scenic way to get between West End and West Bay. These small lanchas (boats) run constantly throughout the day, departing from the West End dock and dropping you right on West Bay Beach in about 5 minutes. It's cheaper than a taxi and infinitely more fun — you get a mini boat ride through turquoise water with the reef visible below. They'll also do custom trips to other spots on the island if you negotiate. The boats are basic but safe, and life jackets are available. Pay in cash (Lempira or USD). During cruise ship days, the boats run more frequently. Last boat back from West Bay is usually around 5pm, so don't miss it or you're walking the hill path.
insiderTip: Last boat back from West Bay is around 5pm — miss it and you're hoofing it up the hill path in the dark. Pay in Lempira to save a few bucks.
addressDescription: Departs from the main dock at the south end of West End village

name: Rusty Fish
description: West End's go-to spot for solid, no-frills seafood at fair prices. The grilled fish plate — whole snapper or grouper with rice, beans, and fried plantains — is one of the best meals you'll have on the island for under $12. The location is right on the main road with a casual open-air setup and plastic chairs, which keeps prices low. The fish is caught that morning from local fishermen, so freshness is never a question. Baleadas are available for breakfast and they're legit — three for a few bucks. The coconut rice is a must-order side. It gets busy at lunch, especially when a cruise ship is in port. No credit cards.
insiderTip: Get the whole grilled snapper with coconut rice — it's the best value meal in West End. Come for breakfast baleadas before your morning dive.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, near the Half Moon Bay area

name: West End Divers
description: A long-established dive shop with a sterling safety record and some of the most experienced instructors on the island. They specialize in small group fun dives and PADI certifications from Open Water through Divemaster. Their boat captains know every dive site on the west side of the reef — from the shallow coral gardens to the deep wall dives at Blue Channel and Hole in the Wall. They use newer Aqualung equipment and replace it regularly. The shop also runs excellent snorkel trips for non-divers, which is handy if your group is split. The dive briefings are thorough without being tedious, and they genuinely care about reef conservation.
insiderTip: Ask about the night dive — it's a completely different reef after dark. The fluorescent dive with UV lights is otherworldly.
addressDescription: Waterfront in West End, near Sundowners Bar

name: Anthony's Key Resort
description: An iconic Roatan resort that's been operating since the 1960s. Set on a private key connected by a bridge to the main island at Sandy Bay, it's famous for its dolphin encounter program through the Roatan Institute for Marine Sciences. The accommodations are charming wooden bungalows surrounded by jungle — no TVs, no AC in the standard rooms (you get sea breeze and fans), which is either paradise or a deal-breaker depending on your personality. The dive operation is top-tier, and the house reef is excellent. Meals are served buffet-style in an open-air pavilion. It's not a luxury resort — it's a nature immersion experience. The dolphin encounters here are ethical and research-based, not the SeaWorld variety.
insiderTip: The dolphin encounter is pricey but genuinely different from tourist-trap swim-with-dolphins programs. Book the snorkel + dolphin combo for the best value.
addressDescription: On a private key in Sandy Bay, connected by a bridge from the main road

name: Creole's Rotisserie Chicken
description: The best rotisserie chicken on the island, and locals will fight you over that claim. Creole's is a no-frills roadside spot in Coxen Hole where whole chickens spin on the rotisserie all day long. The chicken is marinated in a secret spice blend — slightly smoky, a little spicy, incredibly juicy. A quarter chicken with rice, beans, and coleslaw will run you about $4, which is the best lunch deal on the island. The place looks unassuming and you might drive right past it, but follow the smoke and the smell. It's where taxi drivers, construction workers, and anyone who knows Roatan eats lunch. No English menu — just point and say 'pollo.'
insiderTip: Order a whole chicken to split between two people — it's barely more expensive than two quarter-chicken plates. Ask for extra of the green hot sauce.
addressDescription: On the main road through Coxen Hole, near the municipal market

name: Gio's Seafood
description: French Harbour is the fishing capital of Roatan, and Gio's is where the fishermen eat. That should tell you everything. Built right on the water next to the commercial fishing docks, this no-nonsense restaurant serves the freshest seafood on the island at local prices. The fried fish plate with tajadas (fried green plantain chips) is the signature order. The conch soup is rich and hearty — a Honduran classic done right. The king crab legs, when available, are enormous and a fraction of what you'd pay in the US. Don't expect linen tablecloths or fancy presentation. This is plastic-plate, eat-with-your-hands, best-meal-of-your-trip kind of dining.
insiderTip: Ask what came in on the boats today and order that. The king crab legs (when in season) are absurdly good and cheap. Bring cash — no cards.
addressDescription: Right on the waterfront in French Harbour, next to the commercial fishing docks

name: Jungle Top Zipline
description: The most exhilarating zipline course on the island, with 13 platforms stretching across the jungle canopy near the west end of Roatan. The longest line is over 800 feet and gives you insane views of the reef and Caribbean below. Guides are safety-conscious and entertaining — they'll push nervous first-timers just enough without being reckless. The course takes about 2 hours and includes a hanging bridges section through the treetops. It's a popular cruise ship excursion, so if you book independently you'll usually get a less crowded time slot and lower price. Closed-toe shoes required. They provide gloves, harness, and helmet. Not recommended if you're afraid of heights — these are legit high.
insiderTip: Book directly instead of through a cruise excursion — you'll pay 40% less and get a less crowded time slot. Go in the morning when it's cooler.
addressDescription: In the hills above Sandy Bay, signed from the main road

name: Half Moon Bay Beach
description: A small, sheltered cove in West End that's perfect for swimming and snorkeling without the crowds of West Bay. The beach is narrow but the water is calm and crystal clear, with good snorkeling along the rocky edges. Several bars and restaurants line the shore, so you can pop in and out between swims. It's walking distance from all the West End dive shops and hostels. The vibe is more backpacker-chill than resort-fancy. There's usually a rope swing hanging from one of the trees, and you'll see local kids doing flips off the dock. Free to access, though the restaurants expect you to buy something if you use their chairs.
insiderTip: Snorkel along the rocky edges on both sides of the bay for the best fish sightings. The beach chairs at the restaurants are free if you order a drink.
addressDescription: At the southern end of West End village, visible from the main road

name: Blue Bahia Resort
description: A mid-range resort option in Sandy Bay that offers a good balance of comfort and value. The rooms are clean, air-conditioned, and have ocean views from the balconies. The pool area is well-maintained and rarely crowded. They have a small private dock for snorkeling and swimming, plus kayaks and paddleboards for guest use. The on-site restaurant is decent but not remarkable — you'll want to venture to West End or West Bay for dinner most nights. It's quieter than the West Bay resorts, which is either a pro or con depending on what you're after. The staff is genuinely friendly, not just hospitality-script friendly. Good WiFi by Roatan standards.
insiderTip: Request a second-floor room with a balcony for the best views. Use the free kayaks and paddle to the reef for snorkeling — it's just a few hundred meters out.
addressDescription: On the waterfront in Sandy Bay, between West End and Coxen Hole

name: Bodden's Island Tours
description: Bodden's runs the most comprehensive island tour on Roatan, hitting all the major spots in a full-day loop: Iguana Farm, Garifuna village in Punta Gorda, mangrove tunnels near Oak Ridge, a beach stop, and the chocolate factory. Victor Bodden has been doing this for 15+ years and his narration is packed with genuine local history and stories you won't find in any guidebook. The tour uses a comfortable air-conditioned van and includes lunch at a local restaurant. It's the best way to see the whole island if you only have one day (cruise passengers, this is for you). Half-day options are also available if you just want the highlights.
insiderTip: Book the full-day tour — the half-day skips the best parts (Oak Ridge mangroves and Punta Gorda). Victor himself gives the best tours; request him when booking.
addressDescription: Picks up from cruise ports, hotels, or West End/West Bay

name: Roatan Charter Fishing
description: Deep sea fishing doesn't get much better than this. Captain Mike runs half-day and full-day charters out of West End targeting mahi-mahi, wahoo, tuna, and marlin depending on the season. The boat is a well-maintained 32-foot center console with top-quality tackle. Unlike some charter operations that stick close to shore, Captain Mike takes you out to the deep water where the big fish are. All gear, bait, ice, and water are included. They'll clean your catch and you can take it to several local restaurants that will cook it for a small fee. Catches are released unless you want to eat them. Book at least 2-3 days ahead; he's popular with repeat visitors.
insiderTip: Book the early morning departure for the best fishing. Take your catch to Sundowners or Cannibal Cafe — they'll cook it for around $10.
addressDescription: Departs from the main dock in West End

name: Waves of Art Gallery
description: The most interesting art gallery on the island, featuring work by local and regional artists with a Caribbean and marine theme. Owner Rosa curates a collection that ranges from affordable prints and postcards to original oil paintings that'll set you back a few hundred dollars. The gallery also stocks handmade jewelry from Bay Island artisans, wooden carvings, and pottery. Unlike the mass-produced souvenir shops in the cruise port, everything here has a story and a maker behind it. Rosa knows every artist personally and can tell you about each piece. It's tucked into a colorful building on West End's main road and easy to miss if you're not looking.
insiderTip: Ask Rosa about the Garifuna artist collective pieces — they're authentic and support local communities. The small watercolors make perfect travel souvenirs.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, in a colorful blue and yellow building

name: Monkey Trail Zipline & ATV
description: A dual-adventure operation offering both zipline canopy tours and ATV trail rides through the jungle interior of the island. The ATV tour is the standout — a 2-hour ride through muddy jungle trails with stops at scenic overlooks and a waterfall (when it's been raining). You'll get dirty. That's the point. The ziplines are shorter than Jungle Top's but the combination package is great value. Guides are fun and know the trails well. They provide helmets and goggles for the ATVs, plus safety gear for the ziplines. Minimum age for ATVs is 16 (or 12 with a parent driving). Closed-toe shoes required for both activities.
insiderTip: Do the combo ATV + zipline package for the best value. Wear clothes you don't mind getting muddy — the ATV trails are messy after rain.
addressDescription: In the hills above Sandy Bay, signed turnoff from the main highway

name: Sundancer Cabanas
description: Budget-friendly beachfront cabanas right on West Bay Beach — probably the cheapest way to wake up to a million-dollar view. The cabanas are simple wooden structures with fans, mosquito nets, and basic furnishings, but the location makes up for any lack of luxury. You're literally steps from the sand. The shared kitchen lets you save money by cooking some meals, and there's a common area with hammocks and a book exchange. It's popular with backpackers and dive students doing their certification nearby. The owners are helpful with arranging tours and transportation. WiFi works about 60% of the time, which is standard for budget spots on the island.
insiderTip: Book the end cabana (#6) for the most privacy and the best ocean breeze. Use the shared kitchen for breakfasts to save money.
addressDescription: On the north end of West Bay Beach, near the path from West End

name: Thirsty Turtle Bar
description: The rowdiest bar in West End, and that's saying something for a street that's basically one long bar crawl. Thirsty Turtle is the late-night spot where dive instructors, expats, and tourists collide over cheap rum drinks and pool tables. There's no cover charge, drinks are strong for the price, and the music ranges from reggae to classic rock depending on who's DJing. Ladies' night on Wednesdays has half-price cocktails. The upstairs balcony has the best people-watching perch on the main drag. Things don't really get going until 10pm, and the party runs until the last person leaves (sometimes 3am). Expect to lose a flip-flop and gain a friend.
insiderTip: Wednesday is ladies' night with half-price cocktails. Head upstairs for the balcony — best people-watching in West End.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, you'll hear it before you see it

name: Roatan Divers
description: A top-tier dive shop in West Bay that caters to both beginners and experienced divers. What sets them apart is their focus on underwater photography — they offer specialty courses and will lend you a GoPro setup if you don't have your own. The house reef at their location is excellent for night dives, and their boat reaches most west-side sites in under 15 minutes. Instructors are multilingual (English, Spanish, German) and patient with first-timers. Their Discover Scuba program for non-certified divers is well-designed and includes a reef dive, not just a pool session. Equipment is Scubapro and well-maintained. They also do whale shark expeditions in season (October-April).
insiderTip: Ask about the whale shark season trips (Oct-April) — they're extra but unforgettable. The GoPro rental is worth it for your first dive.
addressDescription: On the beachfront in West Bay, next to the main resort area

name: Beachers Bar & Grill
description: Right on West Bay Beach with your feet in the sand while you eat — it doesn't get more Caribbean than this. Beachers does big, American-style portions of burgers, fish tacos, and grilled seafood. The frozen mango daiquiri is enormous and dangerously drinkable. It's touristy, sure, but the food is consistently good and the setting is incredible. They have loungers and umbrellas you can use if you're eating, which saves you the chair rental fee. On cruise ship days it gets slammed between 11am and 2pm, so time your visit accordingly. Service slows down when busy but the bartenders are friendly and keep the drinks flowing. WiFi surprisingly works here.
insiderTip: Order food and get free use of beach loungers — saves you the $10-15 chair rental. Avoid 11am-2pm on cruise ship days.
addressDescription: Right on West Bay Beach, near the middle of the beach stretch

name: Earth Mama Cafe
description: The healthy eating option in West End that doesn't sacrifice flavor. Earth Mama serves smoothie bowls, fresh juices, avocado toast, and plant-based meals that are genuinely good — not just 'good for a small island.' The fruit smoothies use local mangoes, papayas, and coconut, and they're a perfect post-dive recovery meal. They also do excellent coffee, which is a big deal because good coffee is surprisingly hard to find on Roatan despite Honduras being a major coffee-producing country. The space is small but cute, with a garden patio out back. Prices are higher than the local spots but fair for the quality. Popular with yoga types and long-term travelers.
insiderTip: The mango-coconut smoothie bowl is the best breakfast in West End. Try the Honduran single-origin pour-over if you're a coffee nerd.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, near the north end of the village

name: Infinity Bay Spa & Beach Resort
description: The most upscale resort on West Bay Beach, with a massive infinity pool that overlooks the Caribbean. Rooms are modern, spacious, and well-maintained with full kitchens in the condo-style units. The beach here is pristine and the resort's section has loungers, palapas, and attentive service. The spa is the best on the island — not saying much, but it's genuinely relaxing. Multiple restaurants on-site range from casual poolside to more formal seafood dining. It's expensive by Roatan standards but competitive with comparable Caribbean resorts. The concierge can arrange diving, tours, and transportation. Great for couples and families who want comfort without leaving the resort.
insiderTip: Book a condo unit with a kitchen — you'll save a fortune on meals. The sunset view from the infinity pool is the best photo op on the island.
addressDescription: On West Bay Beach, main resort strip

name: Vintage Pearl Brewery
description: A newcomer to the Roatan craft beer scene, Vintage Pearl brews small batches in a converted warehouse space in French Harbour. The taproom is industrial-chic with reclaimed wood furniture and local art on the walls. They typically have 5-6 beers on tap, rotating seasonally. The Mango Wheat is a crowd-pleaser, and the Stout is surprisingly robust for a tropical brewery. They do food pairings on weekends and occasionally host live music. It's off the typical tourist path, which means you'll drink alongside locals and expats rather than cruise passengers. The owner, a former US craft brewer, is passionate about building a beer culture on the island.
insiderTip: Saturday afternoons have the best vibe with food pairings and sometimes live music. Try the seasonal specials — they're always interesting.
addressDescription: In a converted warehouse in French Harbour, near the main road

name: Arch's Iguana & Marine Park
description: One of the most popular attractions on Roatan, especially for families and cruise passengers. This conservation park is home to thousands of iguanas that roam freely — you can hold them, feed them, and take photos. Beyond the iguanas, there's a small marine park with sea turtles, macaws, monkeys, and a botanical garden walk. It's educational and the guides are knowledgeable about the local ecosystem. The park was founded by the late Arch to protect the island's iguana population, and it does genuine conservation work. Visits take about an hour. It gets crowded on cruise ship days between 10am and 1pm. The gift shop is overpriced but the admission fee is reasonable.
insiderTip: Arrive right at opening (9am) to beat the cruise ship crowds. Bring a hat — there's not much shade in the iguana area. Skip the gift shop.
addressDescription: On the main highway in French Harbour, well-signed from the road

name: The Thai Place
description: Yes, there's legitimate Thai food on a Caribbean island, and it's genuinely good. Run by a Thai-Honduran couple, this tiny restaurant in West End dishes out pad thai, green curry, and tom yum soup that would hold up in Bangkok's backpacker district. The portions are generous and prices are fair. The green curry with fresh local shrimp is the standout — creamy, spicy, and fragrant. They use fresh ingredients and the coconut milk comes from actual coconuts. The space seats maybe 20 people, so there can be a wait on busy nights. No reservations, cash preferred. It's a welcome change of pace from fish tacos and baleadas after a week on the island.
insiderTip: The green curry with shrimp is the best thing on the menu. Go early (before 7pm) to avoid the wait — they don't take reservations.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, near the north end

name: Captain Van's Rentals
description: The go-to scooter rental in West Bay. Captain Van keeps a fleet of well-maintained Honda scooters that are perfect for buzzing around the west end of the island. Scooters are the best way to get between West Bay, West End, and Sandy Bay — cheaper than taxis and more fun. He'll deliver to your hotel and pick up when you're done. Helmets are included (and legally required, though enforcement is relaxed). Insurance is included in the daily rate. He also rents kayaks and paddleboards by the hour for exploring the coast. Cash or Venmo accepted. Book through WhatsApp — Van is quick to respond.
insiderTip: Rent a scooter for the day to explore West Bay to Sandy Bay — it's the cheapest and most fun way to get around. Fill up at the gas station near Coxen Hole.
addressDescription: Near the main entrance to West Bay, delivery available

name: Oak Ridge Mangrove Tour
description: A magical boat ride through the mangrove tunnels near Oak Ridge — easily one of the most unique experiences on Roatan. Local fishermen guide you through narrow channels carved through dense mangrove forests, where the tree canopy closes overhead to form natural tunnels. It's quiet, beautiful, and unlike anything else on the island. The tour typically lasts 1-2 hours and includes stops at a local stilted village and sometimes a snorkel spot. The boats are small wooden lanchas and the guides know every twist and turn. This is the real Roatan that most tourists never see. Best done as part of an island tour, or hire a taxi to take you to Oak Ridge independently.
insiderTip: Hire a local fisherman at the Oak Ridge dock rather than booking through a tour company — you'll pay half the price and the experience is more authentic.
addressDescription: Departs from the Oak Ridge town dock on the south shore

name: Happy Town Cigar Company
description: Honduras is one of the world's top cigar producers, and this shop in French Harbour sells locally rolled cigars that rival anything from Cuba or the Dominican Republic. The owner sources tobacco from the Copan region on mainland Honduras and rolls everything in-house. You can watch the rolling process and learn about different tobacco varieties. Prices are a fraction of what you'd pay for comparable quality in the US or Europe. They sell individual sticks and custom boxes. The shop also has a small lounge area where you can smoke a cigar with a glass of rum. Even if you're not a cigar person, the craftsmanship is impressive to watch.
insiderTip: Buy a box of the Maduro blend — it's their best cigar and incredibly cheap compared to US prices. They'll vacuum-seal boxes for travel.
addressDescription: On the main road in French Harbour, near the town center

name: The Blue Channel Dive Site
description: Not a business per se, but the most famous dive site on Roatan's reef and a must-do for certified divers. The Blue Channel is a swim-through canyon in the reef wall that starts at about 50 feet and drops to a sand channel at 120 feet. The wall is covered in sponges, sea fans, and soft corals, and you'll regularly see eagle rays, turtles, and nurse sharks. Visibility is usually 80-100 feet. Most dive shops on the west end include this site in their rotation. It's suitable for Advanced Open Water and above — not a beginner dive due to the depth and current. Morning dives typically have the best visibility and calmest conditions.
insiderTip: Request this site specifically when booking a two-tank dive — not all shops go here every day. Morning dives have the best visibility.
addressDescription: Offshore dive site accessed by boat from West End or West Bay

name: Punta Gorda Garifuna Cultural Tour
description: An immersive cultural experience in the oldest settlement on Roatan. The Garifuna people have lived here for over 200 years, maintaining their unique Afro-Caribbean culture, language, music, and cuisine. This community-run tour includes traditional drumming and Punta dance performances, a cassava bread-making demonstration, and a meal of local Garifuna food (machuca, hudut, coconut bread). The guides are community members who share stories passed down through generations. It's authentic, not a tourist show — this is how the Garifuna community actually lives and celebrates. Tours last about 2-3 hours. Punta Gorda is about a 90-minute drive from West Bay, so plan accordingly.
insiderTip: Ask to try machuca (mashed plantain with coconut fish stew) — it's the quintessential Garifuna dish. Tip the drummers directly; they're community musicians.
addressDescription: In the heart of Punta Gorda village, on the north shore of eastern Roatan

name: Mama's Baleadas
description: The best baleadas on the island. Period. Mama Rosa has been making these Honduran flour tortilla pockets stuffed with refried beans, cheese, and cream since before Roatan had paved roads. Her small roadside stand in Coxen Hole draws everyone from construction workers to dive instructors who make the trip specifically for lunch. The simple baleada is perfect, but the especial with scrambled eggs, avocado, and chorizo is transcendent. Everything is made fresh to order. You'll pay about $1-2 per baleada, making this the best meal deal on the island. There's no English signage — look for the small wooden stall with a line of locals. That's Mama's.
insiderTip: Get the baleada especial with chorizo and avocado — it's worth the extra fifty cents. Arrive before noon or she may run out of avocado.
addressDescription: Small roadside stand on the main road through Coxen Hole, near the market — look for the line

name: La Sirena Cocktail Bar
description: The closest thing to a craft cocktail bar on Roatan. La Sirena (The Mermaid) is a sophisticated open-air lounge in West Bay that serves expertly mixed cocktails using quality spirits and fresh local ingredients. The bartenders actually know what they're doing — proper technique, fresh-squeezed juices, hand-carved ice. The mermaid-themed decor is tasteful rather than tacky. Try the signature Sirena Sour (rum, passion fruit, lime, egg white) or any of the mezcal cocktails. The small plates menu is solid — ceviche, bruschetta, coconut shrimp. It's pricier than your average island bar, but the quality justifies it. Popular with the resort crowd and expats celebrating special occasions.
insiderTip: The Sirena Sour is the signature drink and it's worth the hype. Happy hour 4-6pm has 2-for-1 on select cocktails.
addressDescription: Near the resort area of West Bay, on the road parallel to the beach

name: West Bay Lodge & Spa
description: A boutique hotel with just 12 rooms, offering a more intimate alternative to the big resorts on West Bay. The rooms are beautifully decorated with Caribbean flair, each with a private balcony and ocean or garden view. The small pool and spa area is peaceful and never crowded. They have a tiny but excellent restaurant that serves breakfast and dinner, focusing on fresh seafood with Caribbean-Latin fusion flavors. The staff remembers your name and preferences. It's a 3-minute walk to the beach. Ideal for couples who want quality over quantity, and don't need a giant resort with 300 rooms. Book well in advance during December-March high season.
insiderTip: Book room 8 or 9 for the best ocean views. The restaurant's Tuesday seafood night is exceptional — reserve your spot at breakfast.
addressDescription: Just off the main road to West Bay Beach, set back in the jungle

name: Reef House Resort
description: A solid mid-range option in West End that puts you steps from the dive shops and nightlife. The rooms are clean and comfortable, some with kitchenettes. The pool overlooks the water, and there's a small private dock for swimming and snorkeling. The vibe is more relaxed and social than the resorts — you'll chat with fellow travelers at the pool bar. They have a good working relationship with several dive shops and can arrange packages. The on-site restaurant does a good breakfast. It's not luxury, but it's well-run and the location is perfect for anyone who wants to be in the heart of West End. Good WiFi, decent AC, hot water that works most of the time.
insiderTip: Ask about the dive + stay packages — they have partnerships with nearby shops that can save you 20%. The pool bar happy hour is 3-5pm.
addressDescription: On the waterfront in West End, north end of the village

name: Island Cigar Factory
description: A small cigar rolling operation right on West End's main strip where you can watch master rollers craft cigars from Honduran tobacco. They sell singles and bundles at excellent prices — much less than you'd pay in a US cigar shop for equivalent quality. The friendly staff will walk you through the different blends and strengths, from mild Connecticut-wrapper sticks to full-bodied Maduros. You can smoke on the patio while watching the West End foot traffic go by. They also sell local rum, hot sauce, and coffee — basically a one-stop shop for Honduran souvenir gifts. Everything can be vacuum-sealed for the flight home.
insiderTip: Buy a bundle of 10 instead of singles — the per-cigar price drops significantly. Ask for the Churchill size in the medium blend for a great all-around smoke.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, near the center of the village

name: Miguel's Taxi Service
description: Miguel is the taxi driver everyone on the west end recommends, and for good reason. He's reliable, speaks excellent English, keeps a clean vehicle, and won't rip you off. He does airport pickups, cruise port transfers, and custom island tours. Rates are fair and agreed upon before you get in — no surprises. His SUV comfortably fits 4 passengers with luggage. He'll wait for you at restaurants, dive shops, or beaches and take you back when you're ready. For island tours, he's a knowledgeable guide who shares local history and hidden spots most taxi drivers skip. He's busy, so book via WhatsApp at least a day in advance.
insiderTip: Save Miguel's WhatsApp number on day one — you'll use him repeatedly. Book your airport transfer the night before; he fills up fast during morning flights.
addressDescription: Based in West End, serves the entire island — book via WhatsApp

name: Camp Bay Beach
description: The most remote and untouched beach on Roatan, and that's exactly why it's worth the drive. Camp Bay is on the far eastern end of the island, about 90 minutes from West Bay, and it feels like a different world. Miles of empty sand, coconut palms, and not a resort in sight. The water is calm and shallow, perfect for swimming. There's a small Garifuna community nearby, and a couple of beachside shacks sell cold beers and fried fish when they feel like being open. Bring your own snacks and water just in case. The road to get here is rough — a 4x4 or at least a sturdy rental car is recommended. This is the Roatan that existed before the cruise ships came.
insiderTip: Bring your own food, water, and snorkel gear — there are no reliable shops. The road is rough so get a 4x4 rental or take a taxi.
addressDescription: Eastern tip of Roatan, past Punta Gorda — follow the signs from the main road

name: Eldon's Seafood Restaurant
description: A local institution in French Harbour that serves the kind of seafood that makes you question why anyone eats at tourist restaurants. Eldon's sits right on the dock where the fishing boats come in. The fish soup is legendary — a rich, coconut-milk-based broth loaded with snapper, shrimp, and crab. The fried fish with tajadas is perfectly executed every time. It's a locals' spot, so expect plastic chairs, a TV playing futbol, and some of the best food on the island. Prices are local prices, which means absurdly cheap by tourist standards. No menu in English, but point at what the table next to you is having — it's all good.
insiderTip: Order the sopa de pescado (fish soup) — it's the best bowl of soup on the island. Go at lunch when the fish is freshest off the boats.
addressDescription: On the waterfront in French Harbour, at the fishing dock

name: Native Dive Shop
description: A locally owned dive shop in West End that prides itself on supporting the Roatan community. The instructors are a mix of locals and long-term expat residents who know every nuance of the reef. They're one of the few shops offering freediving courses alongside traditional PADI scuba certifications. Their environmental commitment is genuine — they organize regular reef cleanups and coral restoration dives. Group sizes are kept small (max 4 for fun dives). The shop is laid-back and welcoming, not the high-pressure sales vibe you get at some operations. Equipment is good quality and they're transparent about maintenance schedules. Fair prices with no hidden fees.
insiderTip: Try the freediving intro course — it's a completely different way to experience the reef and cheaper than scuba. Ask about the coral restoration volunteer dives.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, near the south end

name: Celeste Island Boutique
description: A curated shop in West Bay that sells resort wear, handmade jewelry, and artisan goods from Honduras and Central America. The clothing is perfect for island life — flowy dresses, linen shirts, swimwear — and the quality is better than the mass-produced tourist shop stuff. The owner Celeste hand-picks everything and has great taste. Prices are fair for the quality, though not cheap. The Lenca pottery from mainland Honduras is beautiful and packable. The sea glass jewelry is made by a local artist and each piece is unique. It's a nice alternative to the cruise port souvenir shops full of made-in-China keychains.
insiderTip: The sea glass jewelry is handmade by a local artist and genuinely unique — perfect for gifts. Ask Celeste about the Lenca pottery; she knows each artisan.
addressDescription: In the small shopping area near the West Bay resort strip

name: Galaxy Wave Ferry
description: The main ferry service between Roatan and the mainland city of La Ceiba. The Galaxy Wave is a modern catamaran that makes the crossing in about an hour, departing from the ferry terminal in Coxen Hole. It's the most affordable way to get to or from the island if you're not flying. The boat is air-conditioned and has a snack bar. Departures are twice daily (morning and afternoon) in each direction. Seas can be rough, especially in the afternoon — take the morning ferry if you're prone to seasickness. Buy tickets at the terminal or online. Arrive 30 minutes before departure. They also carry cargo, so the terminal can be chaotic.
insiderTip: Take the morning ferry — afternoon seas are rougher and more likely to cause seasickness. Buy tickets online to avoid the line at the terminal.
addressDescription: Ferry terminal at the port of Coxen Hole

name: Coconut Express Tuk-Tuks
description: A fleet of brightly painted tuk-tuks that run between West End and West Bay for a fraction of a regular taxi fare. These three-wheeled vehicles are fun, breezy, and perfect for short hops. They run a regular route along the main road and you can flag one down or find them at designated stops. The ride takes about 10 minutes between the two areas. It's not air-conditioned (obviously) and the road can be bumpy, but that's part of the charm. Most drivers are local characters who'll point out landmarks and crack jokes along the way. Pay in Lempira for the best rate; they accept USD too but at a slightly worse exchange.
insiderTip: Pay in Lempira for a better rate than paying in USD. The tuk-tuk stop at the entrance to West End is the most reliable pickup point.
addressDescription: Flag one down on the main road between West End and West Bay

name: Henry's Supermarket
description: The largest and most well-stocked grocery store on Roatan, located in Coxen Hole. If you're staying in a rental with a kitchen, this is where you do your big shop. They carry a surprisingly good selection of international products alongside local staples — everything from imported cheeses and wines to Honduran coffee and hot sauce. Prices are higher than mainland Honduras but lower than the small shops in West End and West Bay. The produce section has local fruits (mangoes, papayas, pineapples) at good prices. They accept both Lempira and USD, and credit cards work here. There's an ATM out front. The parking lot is chaotic but the store is organized.
insiderTip: Stock up here instead of the overpriced mini-marts in West End. Buy local coffee (Cafe Copan or Cafe Espresso) — it's excellent and cheap.
addressDescription: On the main road in Coxen Hole, near the center of town

name: Romeo's Snorkel Tours
description: Romeo is a third-generation fisherman who runs the most personal snorkel tour operation in West Bay. His small panga takes a max of 6 people to three different reef spots, including a turtle grass area where you're almost guaranteed to swim with sea turtles. Romeo knows the reef like the back of his hand and will point out creatures most people swim right past — cleaning stations, camouflaged scorpionfish, tiny seahorses. The tour includes mask, fins, and snorkel (bring your own if you have them — better quality). He also does a glass-bottom boat option for non-swimmers. Book via WhatsApp; he fills up fast on cruise ship days.
insiderTip: Ask Romeo to take you to the turtle grass beds — he's the only operator who consistently finds sea turtles. Book at least a day ahead on cruise ship days.
addressDescription: Departs from the north end of West Bay Beach, near the water taxi dock

name: Tranquil Seas Eco Lodge
description: An off-grid eco-lodge on the quiet eastern end of the island, perfect for travelers who want to truly disconnect. The lodge runs on solar power, collects rainwater, and composts waste. Accommodation is in comfortable jungle cabins with screened windows and fans — no AC, but the elevation catches a good breeze. The property has a small private beach and excellent house reef for snorkeling. Meals are included and feature local organic produce. The owners are marine biologists who run reef conservation programs you can participate in. It's remote (45 minutes from the airport), which is the whole point. Not for everyone, but transformative for those who get it.
insiderTip: Sign up for the reef restoration program — you'll actually plant coral fragments. Bring a headlamp; the paths aren't lit at night (by design).
addressDescription: On the north shore near Port Royal, accessible by car or boat

name: Jack's Taco Shack
description: A colorful food truck parked permanently at the entrance to West End that serves the best fish tacos on the island. Jack, an American expat who came for a week and stayed 12 years, cures his own fish and makes tortillas from scratch. The blackened mahi-mahi taco with mango salsa and chipotle crema is the signature — one of the best things you'll eat on Roatan. He also does shrimp tacos, a killer pork burrito, and vegan options with grilled plantain and black beans. Everything is under $5. The shack seats maybe 8 people at a counter, but most people grab and walk. Cash only, open until he runs out of food.
insiderTip: The blackened mahi taco is the MUST order. Get there before 1pm — he literally closes when the food runs out, which is usually by 2pm.
addressDescription: Food truck at the entrance to West End, near the main road junction

name: Carambola Botanical Gardens
description: A beautiful tropical garden and nature trail in Sandy Bay that most tourists skip — their loss. The 40-acre property features exotic plants, orchids, spice trees, and native species, all labeled with information about traditional medicinal uses. The main trail loop takes about an hour and winds through the jungle with occasional ocean views. You'll see iguanas, parrots, and butterflies throughout. The guides are knowledgeable about ethnobotany and local ecology. There's a small gift shop selling local spices and natural products. It's a peaceful break from the beach-bar-dive loop and genuinely educational. A good activity for a rest day between dives.
insiderTip: Go in the morning when the birds are most active. The guide included with admission adds way more value — don't skip it.
addressDescription: On the hill above Sandy Bay, signed from the main road

name: Neptune's Seafood Bar
description: A lively sports bar and seafood joint on the main strip in West End. Neptune's is where you watch the game, drink cold beer, and eat fried shrimp baskets without thinking too hard about anything. They have multiple TVs showing NFL, Premier League, and whatever else is on. The conch fritters are addictive, the wings are solid, and the beer is cheap. Thursday night is trivia night, which draws a fun mix of expats, dive instructors, and tourists. The bartenders are friendly and will remember your drink after two visits. It's not trying to be fancy — it's trying to be your neighborhood bar, and it succeeds. Pool table in the back.
insiderTip: Thursday trivia night is the best weeknight activity in West End. Get a team of 4 and you might win a free bar tab.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, central location

name: Bite on the Beach
description: A casual beachfront restaurant on West Bay that does surprisingly good Italian food alongside Caribbean standards. The thin-crust pizzas from the wood-fired oven are excellent, and the pasta is made in-house daily. But the real star is the seafood — the grilled lobster tail (in season) and the coconut shrimp are both outstanding. Tables are set up in the sand, and the ambiance at sunset is magical. Service is island-speed (relaxed), so don't come here if you're in a rush. They have a decent cocktail menu and the mojitos are well-made. Prices are mid-range for West Bay, which means slightly high by island standards but fair for the beachfront setting.
insiderTip: Come at 5pm for the sunset and stay for dinner. The homemade pasta specials (usually Thursday) are worth planning around.
addressDescription: On West Bay Beach, south end near the resorts

name: Pirate's Bay Beach Club
description: A private beach club in Sandy Bay that's worth the admission fee for a day of structured beach fun. The beach is well-maintained with good sand and clear water. Admission includes a lounger, umbrella, and access to the pool and facilities. They have a full-service bar and restaurant on the beach with better-than-average food. There's a cliff jumping platform, rope swings, a waterslide, and kayaks — it's like a water park that doesn't feel corporate. On weekends there's usually live music or DJ. It's popular with the cruise ship crowd, but the facilities handle the volume well. Probably the most 'Instagram-friendly' beach spot on the island.
insiderTip: Go on a non-cruise ship day for a much more relaxed experience. The cliff jump is safe but thrilling — don't overthink it, just go.
addressDescription: On the coast in Sandy Bay, signed from the main road

name: Roatan Paddleboard Adventures
description: Stand-up paddleboard tours and rentals in West Bay. The morning glass-water SUP tour is the best — you'll paddle along the coast, over the reef in crystal-clear water, spotting fish and turtles from above. It's a surprisingly great workout and totally different perspective on the reef compared to snorkeling. They offer beginner lessons, sunset paddles, and full-moon night paddles (when available). Equipment is quality and well-maintained. The owner Sarah is a certified instructor who's patient with beginners. Single-board rentals are also available if you just want to do your own thing. Best conditions are early morning before the wind picks up.
insiderTip: The sunrise paddle at 6am is the most serene experience on the island — calm water, empty beach, dolphins sometimes appear. Book the night before.
addressDescription: On West Bay Beach, near the water taxi dock at the north end

name: Flowers Bay Fish Shack
description: A hidden gem near the airport that most tourists never find. This tiny roadside fish shack in Flowers Bay serves the freshest fried fish you'll eat on the island, cooked by a local family who've been doing it for decades. The menu is simple: fried fish, fried chicken, tajadas, rice and beans. That's it. And it's all you need. The fish is caught that morning by the family's own boats, and the seasoning is a closely guarded family recipe. Prices are local — meaning absurdly cheap. There are a few plastic tables under a palapa roof, and the sound of chickens and reggaeton from the next house completes the ambiance. This is real Roatan.
insiderTip: Ask for the whole fried red snapper — it's the best thing on the menu. Go at lunch (11am-1pm) when the fish is freshest.
addressDescription: Small fish shack on the road through Flowers Bay, near the airport turn-off

name: Island Riders Golf Cart Rental
description: Golf carts are the fun way to cruise around the west end of Roatan, and Island Riders has the best fleet. Their carts are newer, well-maintained, and come in both 4-seater and 6-seater models. Perfect for families or groups who want to explore West Bay, West End, and Sandy Bay at their own pace. They're street-legal on the main roads (stay off the highway to Coxen Hole — it's too fast for golf carts). Rates are per day and include a full charge. They'll deliver to your hotel and pick up when you're done. Insurance included. It's the most fun form of transportation on the island, and everyone will wave at you.
insiderTip: Stick to the roads between West Bay and Sandy Bay — the main highway is too fast for golf carts. Charge overnight at your hotel if renting multiple days.
addressDescription: Near the main entrance to West Bay, offers hotel delivery

name: Tropical Treasures
description: The best souvenir shop near the Mahogany Bay cruise port, and the only one where you won't feel like you're being ripped off. While the port shops charge cruise-ship premiums for generic souvenirs, Tropical Treasures (just outside the port area) sells locally made crafts, Honduran coffee, rum, hot sauce, and bay island art at fair prices. The wooden carvings are made by a cooperative of island artisans and each piece is unique. They also stock reef-safe sunscreen, which you should be using but probably forgot to buy. The staff is helpful and not pushy. A good first stop before heading to the beach.
insiderTip: Buy your souvenirs here instead of inside the cruise port — prices are 30-50% lower for the same products. Stock up on Honduran coffee and hot sauce.
addressDescription: Just outside the Mahogany Bay cruise port area, on the main road

name: The Jolly Roger
description: A pirate-themed bar in West End that takes itself exactly the right amount of seriously — which is to say, not very. The decor is full-on pirate ship, complete with skull-and-crossbones flags and a wooden bar shaped like a ship's bow. But the drinks are genuinely good and the Friday night karaoke is the most entertaining free show on the island. They serve strong rum punches, decent frozen cocktails, and buckets of beer at group prices. The crowd is mostly young travelers and dive professionals blowing off steam. The bar food (nachos, wings, quesadillas) is reliable drunk food. Saturday nights usually have a DJ or live music. It's cheesy and fun and you'll end up here at least once.
insiderTip: Friday karaoke is must-see entertainment — the dive instructors' performances are legendary. The rum punch is dangerously strong; pace yourself.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, hard to miss with the pirate flags

name: Paradise Divers
description: A well-run dive shop in Sandy Bay that specializes in drift dives and advanced dive experiences. If you're already certified and want to up your game, this is your spot. They run trips to the less-visited east-side dive sites, including Mary's Place — a stunning crack in the reef wall that you swim through. The instructors are experienced (most have 3000+ dives logged) and passionate about marine biology. They also offer PADI Advanced Open Water, Rescue Diver, and Divemaster courses. Equipment is Aqualung and well-maintained. Group sizes max at 5 divers. They're not the cheapest, but the experience and site selection justify the premium.
insiderTip: Request the Mary's Place dive — it's the most dramatic dive site on the island and not every shop goes there. Advanced certification required.
addressDescription: On the waterfront in Sandy Bay, near the marine research center

name: La Palapa Sunset Bar
description: A breezy beachfront palapa bar on West Bay that does happy hour right. From 3pm to 6pm, cocktails are two-for-one and the sunset show is free. The bar is built on stilts over the water with a thatched roof and open sides — you feel like you're floating on the Caribbean. The bartenders make a killer frozen piña colada and the ceviche appetizer is fresh and zesty. It's attached to one of the resorts but open to non-guests. The vibe is mellow and sophisticated compared to the rowdy West End bars — more couples and older travelers than backpackers. On calm days, you can swim right off the deck. One of the most photogenic spots on the island.
insiderTip: Happy hour 3-6pm is the best deal — two-for-one cocktails while watching the sunset from over-water seating. Non-guests are welcome.
addressDescription: Over-water palapa on West Bay Beach, south end near the resorts

name: Glass Bottom Boat Tours
description: Perfect for people who want to see the reef without getting wet. These glass-bottom boats depart from West End and cruise over the reef for about an hour, giving you a window into the underwater world. You'll see coral formations, tropical fish, and sometimes turtles and rays gliding underneath. It's ideal for young kids, elderly travelers, or anyone who's not comfortable snorkeling. The boats are well-maintained with clear glass panels and comfortable seating. Commentary from the guides is informative and fun. Some tours combine with a snorkel stop for those who want to jump in. Runs multiple times daily; no reservation needed for most departures.
insiderTip: The morning tours have clearer water for better viewing. Combine with a snorkel stop if anyone in your group wants to get in the water.
addressDescription: Departs from the main dock in West End, near the water taxi

name: La Casa del Sol
description: A small Italian-owned restaurant in West End that serves the most authentic Italian food on the island. Chef Marco imports key ingredients (San Marzano tomatoes, Parmigiano-Reggiano, Italian flour) and makes everything from scratch — the pasta, the bread, the desserts. The four-cheese ravioli is sublime, and the tiramisu is the best dessert on the island. The setting is a candlelit garden patio with just 10 tables, creating an intimate atmosphere. It's not cheap, but the quality is genuine. Reservations are essential on weekends — this is a small operation and they turn people away regularly. BYOB is allowed with a small corkage fee, though the wine list is adequate.
insiderTip: Reserve for dinner — they only have 10 tables and fill up fast. The tiramisu is made fresh daily and it's spectacular. BYOB to save on wine.
addressDescription: On a side path off the main road in West End, look for the string lights

name: Port Royal Beach
description: A remote beach on the eastern end of the island with historical significance — this was once a stronghold for English pirates and privateers. The beach is pristine, uncrowded, and backed by coconut palms and jungle. The water is calm on most days, good for swimming but not great for snorkeling (sandy bottom). The ruins of an old English fort are nearby and worth exploring. Getting here requires a 4x4 or boat from Oak Ridge. There are no facilities — bring everything you need. You might have the entire beach to yourself. For history buffs and adventure travelers, this is one of the most atmospheric spots on the island.
insiderTip: Explore the old fort ruins uphill from the beach. Bring all supplies — there's nothing here. Best accessed by boat from Oak Ridge for a more scenic route.
addressDescription: Eastern end of Roatan, near the old fort ruins — accessible by rough road or boat

name: Roatan Helicopter Tours
description: See the island from above — the reef, the jungle, the coastline — in a way that no boat or road trip can match. These 20-minute helicopter tours depart from near the airport and fly along the west coast, giving you aerial views of West Bay Beach, the barrier reef, and the deep blue beyond. It's expensive, but if you're celebrating something special or just want a once-in-a-lifetime experience, it's worth it. The pilot is experienced and narrates the flight. Doors-off flights are available for photographers. Weight limits apply (they'll ask when you book). This is the most dramatic way to appreciate how small and beautiful this island really is.
insiderTip: Book the doors-off flight if you want incredible photos (and don't mind the wind). Morning flights have less haze for clearer views.
addressDescription: Near Juan Manuel Galvez International Airport, Flowers Bay

name: Cafe Escondido
description: A charming little coffee shop and brunch spot tucked away on a side street in West End. The name means 'Hidden Cafe' and it lives up to it — most people walk right past the entrance. Inside, it's a cozy space with local art on the walls and excellent coffee made from single-origin Honduran beans roasted locally. The breakfast menu features eggs Benedict, French toast with local fruit, and the best avocado toast on the island. They also do fresh juices and smoothies. Portions are generous and everything is prepared with care. It's become the morning meeting spot for long-term expats. WiFi is reliable, making it a decent work spot.
insiderTip: The eggs Benedict with smoked fish is a hidden menu item — ask for it. This is the best WiFi in West End, so bring your laptop.
addressDescription: On a side path off the main road in West End, near the north end — look for the small wooden sign

name: Coconut Joe's Beach Bar
description: The quintessential Caribbean beach bar in West Bay. Coconut Joe's sits right on the sand with a palapa roof, a wooden bar top, and the kind of atmosphere that makes you immediately order a rum drink and forget about your real life. The fish tacos are surprisingly good for a bar, and the coconut shrimp are always a hit. They have a good sound system that plays reggae and island vibes during the day, ramping up to danceable stuff on weekend nights. Beach chairs and loungers come free with food orders. The bar is popular with a younger crowd and gets lively by late afternoon. Great spot for cruise passengers who want a beach day with easy food and drinks.
insiderTip: Order food and get free beach chairs — better than paying $15 to rent them. The fish tacos are the best food option here.
addressDescription: On West Bay Beach, north end near the water taxi drop-off

name: Roatan Airport Shuttle Service
description: A reliable shared shuttle service between Juan Manuel Galvez Airport and the major tourist areas. They meet every incoming flight with a comfortable air-conditioned van and drop passengers at hotels in West End, West Bay, and Sandy Bay. The price is per person and much cheaper than a private taxi. The van waits until it's full (usually 10-15 minutes after landing), then makes drops in order. The return service picks you up at your hotel 3 hours before your flight. Booking via WhatsApp is recommended but they also have a desk at the airport arrivals area. They're punctual and professional — important when you need to catch a flight.
insiderTip: Book your return shuttle the night before your flight via WhatsApp. The shared shuttle is half the price of a private taxi to West End.
addressDescription: Operates from Juan Manuel Galvez Airport (RTB), Flowers Bay

name: Tabyana Beach
description: A managed beach club near West Bay that's a popular cruise ship excursion destination. The beach itself is gorgeous — white sand, clear water, good snorkeling off a dock. The setup includes loungers, umbrellas, a bar, and a restaurant. It's more organized and touristy than West Bay Beach proper, but that structure is actually useful if you only have 6 hours on the island and don't want to figure things out yourself. Snorkel gear, kayaks, and paddleboards are available to rent. They also offer banana boat rides and other water toys. Gets crowded on multi-ship days but handles the volume well. Not the authentic island experience, but a good, reliable beach day.
insiderTip: Book independently online rather than through the cruise ship excursion desk — you'll save significantly. Head to the far right end for less crowded snorkeling.
addressDescription: South end of West Bay Beach, near the cruise excursion area

name: Bay Island Chocolate Factory
description: A bean-to-bar chocolate factory tour that's unexpectedly fascinating. The factory uses cacao from mainland Honduras (the Copan and Mosquito Coast regions have some of the best cacao in the Americas) to make small-batch artisan chocolate. The tour walks you through the entire process — from raw cacao pods to finished bars — and includes tastings throughout. You'll never look at a Hershey bar the same way again. The gift shop sells bars, nibs, and cocoa powder that make excellent souvenirs. The hot chocolate made from their pure cocoa paste is extraordinary. It's a popular cruise excursion stop, so mornings can be crowded. Go after 2pm for a quieter experience.
insiderTip: Go after 2pm to avoid the cruise ship tour groups. Buy the 85% dark bar and the cacao nibs — they're exceptional and lightweight souvenirs.
addressDescription: On the main road just east of West End, before Sandy Bay

name: El Palenque Steakhouse
description: When you've had enough seafood and need red meat, El Palenque delivers. This Honduran-style steakhouse in Coxen Hole serves thick, juicy cuts of beef grilled over charcoal. The churrasco (grilled skirt steak) with chimichurri and fried plantains is the signature, and it's massive. They also do excellent pork chops and grilled chicken. The sides — refried beans, tortillas, grilled peppers — are all on point. It's a local place with local prices, so you'll eat well for under $10. The dining room is basic but clean. Popular with islanders for family dinners on weekends. No pretension, just really good grilled meat at fair prices.
insiderTip: The churrasco is enormous — consider splitting it. Ask for extra chimichurri and the spicy pickled onions (curtido) on the side.
addressDescription: On the main road through Coxen Hole, near the hospital

name: Sea Breeze Inn
description: A no-frills guesthouse in West End that offers the cheapest private rooms in the tourist area. The rooms are basic — bed, fan, small bathroom — but they're clean and the location is unbeatable. You're right on the main strip, walking distance to every dive shop, bar, and restaurant. There's a shared kitchen and a rooftop terrace with ocean views. The owner Doris is a West End institution who knows everything about the island and will help you arrange tours, dives, and transportation. It's perfect for budget travelers who want to spend their money on diving and eating rather than on a fancy room they'll barely use. Book directly via WhatsApp for the best rate.
insiderTip: Book directly via WhatsApp for a lower rate than booking sites. Room 4 on the top floor has the best breeze and a partial ocean view.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, near the center of the village

name: Roatan Kayak Adventures
description: Kayak tours and rentals in West End, offering single and tandem kayaks to explore the coastline. The guided mangrove kayak tour is the highlight — a peaceful paddle through mangrove channels where you'll see birds, fish, and the occasional manatee. Self-guided rentals come with a waterproof map of the best paddling routes. The sunset kayak tour is romantic and popular with couples. All kayaks are sit-on-top style and easy for beginners. Life jackets and dry bags included. They also rent snorkel gear as an add-on so you can pull up on a reef spot and jump in. Located right on the water so launching is easy.
insiderTip: The morning mangrove tour has the best wildlife sightings — bring binoculars for the birds. Add snorkel gear rental for a complete water day.
addressDescription: On the waterfront at the south end of West End, near Half Moon Bay

name: Paradise Beach Club
description: An upscale beach club on West Bay that offers a premium beach experience with quality food and cocktails. The day pass includes a lounger with umbrella, pool access, and a drink credit. The infinity pool overlooking the ocean is stunning and rarely crowded on non-cruise ship days. The restaurant serves elevated Caribbean fusion — think coconut-crusted grouper with mango salsa and micro greens, not just fish and chips. The cocktail program features fresh tropical ingredients and local rum. It's pricier than the casual beach bars, but you're paying for quality service, clean facilities, and a curated atmosphere. Popular with couples and resort guests.
insiderTip: Visit on a Tuesday or Thursday for the quietest experience. The coconut-crusted grouper is the best thing on the menu.
addressDescription: West Bay Beach, mid-section near the luxury resorts

name: Oak Ridge Water Village Tour
description: Oak Ridge is a working fishing village built entirely on stilts over the water — one of the most picturesque and authentic settlements in the Bay Islands. This boat tour takes you through the narrow waterways between colorful wooden houses, past fishing boats and kids diving off their porches. A local guide explains the history and daily life of the community. You'll stop at a traditional boat-building workshop where artisans still craft wooden fishing boats by hand using techniques passed down through generations. The tour includes a fresh seafood lunch at a stilted restaurant over the water. It's a 45-minute drive from West Bay, but absolutely worth the trip for a window into real island life.
insiderTip: Combine this with the mangrove tour for a full day on the east side. The boat builder's workshop is the highlight — tip the craftsmen directly.
addressDescription: Tour departs from the Oak Ridge main dock on the south shore

name: Mango's Caribbean Grill
description: A popular mid-range restaurant on West Bay that does Caribbean comfort food exceptionally well. The jerk chicken is marinated for 24 hours and grilled over pimento wood — the real deal, not the watered-down tourist version. The blackened fish sandwich is piled high with fresh catch and a tangy slaw. The mango BBQ ribs (their namesake dish) fall off the bone. The restaurant has a fun, colorful atmosphere with an open kitchen so you can watch the grill action. They have a full bar with creative tropical cocktails. Service is friendly and efficient. It's one of the few places in West Bay where you can eat well without spending resort prices.
insiderTip: The jerk chicken is the real thing — if you like heat, ask for the extra-spicy version. Happy hour 4-6pm has great cocktail deals.
addressDescription: On the road to West Bay Beach, near the resort area

name: Yaba Ding Ding Art Gallery
description: A colorful art gallery and studio in Coxen Hole that showcases work by local Bay Island artists. The gallery gets its quirky name from island slang and the energy inside matches — it's vibrant, eclectic, and full of personality. You'll find original paintings of island life, hand-painted signs, driftwood sculptures, and photography prints. The prices are significantly lower than the touristy galleries in West End, and you're buying directly from (or very close to) the artists. The owner actively supports emerging local artists and hosts occasional art nights with live painting. A great place to find an authentic Roatan souvenir that isn't a keychain.
insiderTip: Prices here are much lower than tourist-area galleries for similar quality. Ask about commissioning a custom piece — the turnaround is usually a few days.
addressDescription: In central Coxen Hole, near the municipal market

name: Reef Runners Dive Shop
description: A small dive operation in French Harbour that focuses on the less-visited east-side dive sites. While most tourists dive the west end of the reef, Reef Runners takes you to pristine sites near French Harbour and Oak Ridge that see far fewer divers — meaning healthier coral and more marine life. Their signature trip visits a grouper spawning aggregation site (seasonal) that's genuinely world-class. The operation is run by a marine biologist who leads most dives personally, turning each trip into an educational experience. They have a fast boat that gets you to sites quickly. Small operation, max 6 divers, very personal service.
insiderTip: The east-side sites are less dived and in better condition than the popular west-end sites. Ask about the seasonal grouper aggregation dives.
addressDescription: At the French Harbour marina, near the commercial docks

name: The BBQ Barn
description: An American-style BBQ joint in West End run by a Texas expat who brought his smoker with him to the Caribbean. The brisket is smoked for 14 hours, the ribs are fall-off-the-bone tender, and the pulled pork sandwich is piled high. Sides include coleslaw, baked beans, cornbread, and mac and cheese. It's a welcome change from seafood after a few days on the island. Portions are Texas-sized, prices are reasonable, and the sauce selection covers everything from sweet Kansas City-style to vinegar-based Carolina. They smoke limited quantities daily, so when it's gone, it's gone — usually by 7pm on busy nights. Grab a Salva Vida or one of their bourbon cocktails.
insiderTip: The brisket sells out first — arrive before 6pm on busy nights. The 'Meat Sweats Platter' for two people is the best value on the menu.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, near the north end — follow the smoke smell

name: Seagrape Plantation Resort
description: A quiet, adults-only retreat nestled on a hillside between West End and West Bay with sweeping ocean views. The rooms are spacious with private balconies, AC, and tasteful Caribbean decor. The infinity pool looks out over the reef — you can see diving boats from your lounger. The on-site restaurant does a great breakfast (included) and dinner is available by reservation. There's a shuttle to both West Bay Beach and West End every hour, so you're not isolated despite the hillside location. The property has beautifully maintained tropical gardens and a genuine sense of tranquility that the busier resorts can't match. Perfect for couples looking for peace without total seclusion.
insiderTip: Book an ocean-view room on the upper level — the views at sunrise are spectacular. The hourly shuttle to West Bay Beach is complimentary.
addressDescription: On the hillside between West End and West Bay, overlooking the ocean

name: The Green Iguana Sports Bar
description: French Harbour's main hangout spot for expats and locals who want cold beer, sports on TV, and bar food without the tourist markup. Multiple flat screens show NFL, NBA, Premier League, and UFC fights. The burgers are thick and juicy — the 'Iguana Burger' with jalapeños and pepper jack cheese is a local legend. They also do wings in a dozen different sauces, loaded nachos, and decent pizza. Pool tables, darts, and a jukebox round out the classic sports bar experience. Weekend nights get lively with a mix of marina workers, fishermen, and expats. It's the kind of place where everyone knows each other and newcomers are welcomed with a cold one.
insiderTip: Come for UFC fight nights — the atmosphere is electric. The Iguana Burger is one of the best burgers on the island.
addressDescription: On the main road through French Harbour, near the marina

name: Bay Island Souvenir Market
description: A covered market near the Mahogany Bay cruise port with about 20 vendor stalls selling souvenirs, crafts, and local products. Quality varies widely between stalls — some sell mass-produced trinkets while others have genuinely nice handmade items. The wooden carvings from the Garifuna stalls and the woven baskets from the Lenca-inspired vendors are the best finds. Haggling is expected and part of the experience — start at about 60% of the asking price and meet in the middle. The vendors are friendly and persistent. It's most lively on cruise ship days. Best strategy: walk through once to scope everything out, then go back to buy from the stalls that caught your eye.
insiderTip: Haggle — starting prices are tourist prices. Walk the entire market first, then go back to buy. The wooden carvings at stalls 12-15 are the best quality.
addressDescription: Near the Mahogany Bay cruise port entrance, covered outdoor market

name: Coconut Express Sushi Bar
description: Sushi on a Caribbean island might sound suspect, but Coconut Express pulls it off surprisingly well. The chef is Japanese-trained and uses fresh local fish — the yellowfin tuna and mahi rolls use fish caught that morning. The menu blends traditional Japanese sushi with Caribbean twists: the 'Island Roll' with coconut shrimp tempura and mango is their signature. They also do poke bowls and sashimi platters. The restaurant is small but stylish, with a counter where you can watch the chef work. It's not cheap — fresh sushi-grade fish on an island doesn't come at mainland prices. Open for dinner only, and reservations are smart on weekends.
insiderTip: Sit at the counter and let the chef make you an omakase-style selection of whatever's freshest. The Island Roll is a must-try.
addressDescription: On the main road in West End, near the center

name: Herby's Garifuna Bar
description: A local Garifuna bar in Punta Gorda that serves gifiti — the traditional Garifuna spirit made by soaking roots, herbs, and bark in rum. Herby makes his own gifiti using recipes passed down from his grandmother, and the result is a potent, slightly bitter, allegedly medicinal drink that you'll either love or struggle to finish. Either way, you need to try it — it's an essential Roatan cultural experience. The bar also serves cold beers and simple Garifuna food (fried fish, machuca). On weekend evenings there's sometimes live Punta drumming. It's as far from a tourist bar as you can get on the island, and that's exactly the point.
insiderTip: Try the gifiti — it's the traditional Garifuna spirit and an experience you can only have here. Start with a small pour; it's an acquired taste.
addressDescription: In the heart of Punta Gorda village, on the main path near the beach

name: Sandy Bay Beach
description: A quieter, less-developed beach than West Bay with excellent shore snorkeling and a fraction of the crowds. Sandy Bay Beach is a residential area, so there are no beach clubs or chair rental operations — just sand, water, and peace. The reef here is accessible from shore and in good condition because fewer people visit. You'll often have large stretches of beach to yourself, even during peak season. The bottom is a mix of sand and turtle grass, and you'll frequently see stingrays in the shallows. There are a couple of small restaurants within walking distance but bring your own shade setup if you want to spend the day. Parking is informal along the road.
insiderTip: This is the best shore snorkeling on the island with the fewest people. Bring your own umbrella and snorkel gear — there's nothing to rent here.
addressDescription: Along the coast in Sandy Bay, access from the main road through several informal paths

name: Blue Moon Lounge
description: A chill lounge bar on the West End waterfront that attracts a slightly older, more laid-back crowd than the rowdy party bars down the strip. The music is a curated mix of jazz, bossa nova, and acoustic sets from local musicians. The cocktail list features classic drinks made well — proper mojitos, daiquiris, and old fashioneds. The sunset view from the overwater deck is among the best on the island, and the atmosphere is perfect for conversation rather than shouting over bass drops. They serve small plates — bruschetta, hummus, cheese boards — that pair nicely with the drinks. Open Wednesday through Sunday, closing relatively early by West End standards.
insiderTip: Live acoustic music on Friday and Saturday evenings, starting at 7pm. The deck seating over the water is the most romantic bar spot in West End.
addressDescription: On the waterfront in West End, near the south end of the strip

name: Beach Bum's Bar & Grill
description: A sandy-floor, barefoot bar on the West Bay beachfront that embodies everything you came to the Caribbean for. Cold drinks, warm sand between your toes, and zero pretension. The house rum punch is mixed in big batches and served in mason jars — they're strong and cheap, a dangerous combination under the island sun. The food is basic but hits the spot: grilled shrimp skewers, fish sandwiches, loaded nachos, and fresh fruit plates. Beach Bum's is owned by a Canadian couple who quit their desk jobs and never looked back. The energy is infectious, the staff is always smiling, and the playlist is perfectly calibrated tropical vibes. Come for lunch, stay until sunset.
insiderTip: The rum punch pitcher is the best deal on the beach — enough for four generous servings. They have a power outlet at the bar for charging phones.
addressDescription: On West Bay Beach, between the major resort properties
